clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of a Compliant Arm Support on Post-stroke Upper Extremity Range of Motion
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Post-Stroke Upper Extremity Assistance

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, we aim to show that a wearable compliant arm support consisting of inflatable bladders with adjustable straps to connect them to the waist and arm can meaningfully increase the reachable workspace of persons with post-stroke arm weakness.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent change from baseline in reachable workspace
primary_outcome.time_frame: 0 and 1/2 hour post-dose with a 1-week follow up
primary_outcome.description: We will measure the reachable workspace of post-stroke participants without support from the compliant arm support as a baseline measurement using a PhaseSpace motion capture system or pose estimation software. These measurements will be recorded as an area (in square centimeters or meters). We will repeat these measurements with the compliant arm support and at prespecified time points after removing the arm support. We will report the percent change from the baseline measurement in reachable work space.

clinical_study.condition: Weakness of Extremities as Sequela of Stroke

intervention.description: Participants will be given compliant arm support and their reachable workspace measured

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- greater than 6 months post-stroke
- passive abduction to 90 degrees at shoulder
- reduced active (retro)flexion/extension at shoulder when abducted to 90 degrees
- reduced active flexion/extension at elbow
Exclusion Criteria:
- unable to give informed consent
- unable to comprehend and follow instructions
- have a condition (other than stroke) affecting sensorimotor function
- show evidence of unilateral spatial neglect
- unable to sit in a chair without armrests for 2 hours

reference.citation: Simpson, C. S., Okamura, A. M., & Hawkes, E. W. (2017, May). Exomuscle: An inflatable device for shoulder abduction support. In 2017 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) (pp. 6651-6657). IEEE.
